A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: MRS. CHARLOTTE M.C. BRICE.

2. Your address: R.R. 2, MASON RD., LANGLEY PRAIRIE, B.C.

3. Date: April 9th, 1955.

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): GREENOCK, SCOTLAND.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   WILLIAM H. ADAM, SURGEON IN THE ROYAL NAVY (for 45 yrs).

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year):
   June 9th, 1894.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   I was only 6 weeks old when I left Scotland and I lived in England, in different parts, as my father was a surgeon in the Navy until I came.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   I was in my teens.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   I came out from England with my parents and my youngest brother, to see two of my brothers who had come out to Sask. several years before, and were ranching in the "Torchwood Hills". And as we all liked the West, my father bought a home there.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    Through my two older brothers, who had come West several years before. And as they liked the freedom of the West, they decided to take up ranching, and would write home to us in England, telling of the interesting life in the West.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so.

It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: MRS. PHAROAH M. C. BRICE
2. Your address: R.R. #3, MASON RANGE, PRairie B.C.
3. Date: 9/19/55
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): GREENOCK, SCOTLAND
5. What was your father's name and occupation? WILLIAM H. ADAM SURGEON IN THE ROYAL NAVY (for 14 years)
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? January 9th, 1894
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

I came out from England with my parents and my youngest brother to see two of my brothers who had come out to Sask. Several years before, and were ranching in the "Scotchwood Hills". And as we all liked the West, they started brought a farm there.

Through my two older brothers, who had been there several years before, and as they liked the freedom of the West, they decided to try life pioneering. Brice would write home to us in England, telling of the interesting life on the West.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   I came with my parents, and youngest brother.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   We left Liverpool, England by boat to Montreal and came from Montreal by the C.P.R. train to what is now Regina, Sask. We stayed at the Lansdowne Hotel for two days, and we then went North of Regina to the Touchwood Hills in a buckboard.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   I remember first meeting William Bries (who was later my husband) and as he had come out from England in 1893 to the N.W.T. and was then ranching in the Touchwood Hills. He came to Regina with my oldest brother in a Wagon, to take our luggage out. And they also bought an extra team of horses to hitch to a buckboard which my father had got in Regina to travel North in about 85 miles. My brother drove the Wagon and Mr. Bries the buckboard.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   After the first two days in Regina she stopped over night on our way to the buckboard at the farm instructors (Mr. & Mrs. Gooderham) on the Piapot Reserve.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   My father bought a comfortable log home in the little Touchwood Hills.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   I lived in the little Touchwood Hills in Sask. from 1894 until 1951. When I came to happy Prairie, B.C.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   As I was just in my teens when I came out with my parents from England I lived with them until I was married in 1895. And my husband ranched in the little Touchwood district on the place he took up in about 1884. And he also practised his Veterinary Profession in later years.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I came with my parents, and my youngest brother.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We left Liverpool England by boat to Montreal, Canada, then by train to Regina, Saskatchewan, where we stayed at the Dominion Hotel for two days, and we went by train to the town of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

14. What incidents of the journey were you most excited about? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Remember first meeting William Briceland who was later my husband! And as he had come out from England in 1883 to the N.W.T. and was then living in the Sourwood Hills, I'd come to Regina with my oldest brother in a wagon, to take our luggage out. And they also bought an entire team of horses to hitch to a buckboard which my father had got in Alberta to travel North in about 85 miles.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

After the trip, we stayed at the Dominion Hotel at the Prince Albert Station for about two weeks.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

My mother bought a homestead by home in the little town of Sourwood Hills in Saskatchewan.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I lived on the Little Sourwood Hills in Saskatchewan from 1894 until 1951. Before coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

As I was very young when I came out with my parents to Western Canada, I didn't work. However, I was married in 1895 and my husband worked in the fields, although he didn't own the place. He took us in about 1884 and also started his plumbing profession in 1885.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

We wrote quite often, but the post-office in the early days was about 25 miles, the nearest being Kikawa, an Indian word meaning "the end of the cliff."

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My husband's name was Wm. Brice. We were married in 1895, June 11th, at a little log Anglican church at the mission on Gordon's Reserve by Bishop Burn, who came up in a buckboard from Qu'Appelle to perform the marriage ceremony. Mrs. Burn also accompanied her husband.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

My oldest brother William Adam came out from England in about 1889. Another brother Jim came out about a year or so later. My brother Charlie came when I did in 1894. And my brother Stephen, who was in the Navy, came out about 1898. They farmed and made their homes in Touchwood.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My oldest brother William Adam came out from England in about 1889. Another brother Jim came out about a year or so later. My brother Charlie came when I did in 1894. And my brother Stephen, who was in the Navy, came out about 1898. They farmed and made their homes in Touchwood.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I am enclosing on a separate paper some of my experiences. And you perhaps could pick out the one you find the most interesting.

All these times in the early days I can remember, were very happy times to me, and I think to most of the early pioneers of Sask.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

In the early years there were not so many in the district, but ones that were there were very friendly with each other, and we would often visit traveling by horse & buggy, also riding horseback, and in the winter with a horse and sleigh.

Church service was held in a neighbor's house several times a year. And some of the babies in the district would be baptized at these services. The closest church was on the Gordon's Reserve about ten miles away.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

We wrote quite often, but the post office was very slow.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My husband's name was William Brice. We were married in 1895 at a little Baptist church near the mission in Graham County.

21. Did anyone else come to Graham County because of your experiences there?

Yes, my oldest brother William came out from England in about 1889. Another brother came out about a year or so later. They brought Charlie Evans when he died in 1894. And my second brother Stephen who was only 16 years old came out about 1898.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My oldest brother William came out from England in about 1889. Another brother came out about a year or so later. They brought Charlie Evans when he died in 1894. And my second brother Stephen who was only 16 years old came out about 1898.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I am writing on a separate paper some of my experiences. But you probably could pick out the ones you liked the most.

All these times in the early days of our memories were very happy times to me. But I think of mostly of the early pioneers of Graham County.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) how often? How far? By what means of travel?

In the early years, this was not so easy in the district. But now that we have cars, families with each other, but not until you had traveled by horse & buggy, also riding horses.

Church service was held in a neighbor's house several times a year. And some of the babies in the district would be baptized at the nearest river about ten miles away.

   About 1917.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

She came to Saskatchewan to visit my two brothers. And as we liked the life in the old country we decided to stay. And of course, married the following year. They parents lived the rest of their lives in Sask.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   About 1917.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What makes?
   We owned a Ford car in 1914.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Our trading center was near the Red River Region, etc.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns, etc.)
   We continued to trade at this point for many years. And then there was the railroad.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   We had to travel quite a distance away. Now there are stores closer by.

30. What (if any) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   Not until the people had cars in general.

31. When (if ever) did you begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   I am not sure of this, but I think it would be around 1900.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   We had our first phone in 1919.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   We came to Saskatchewan to visit my two brothers. And as we liked the life in the older we decided to stay. And it was practical the following year.

My parents lived the rest of their lives in Sask.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

By the late Mr. William Brown, was one of the chief citizens of Queen Victoria, and when Sarah was born at the N.W.T., he belonged to the Masonic Lodge Consolidated Fraternal Union No. 91, which was organized in 1872.

If you or any of your family are friends of the Fraternal Order of Eagles, or have anything in the district mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

My husband was chairman of the first "Little Yeadwood School" in 1912. It was built about 1930, but later years a stampede was held on our ranch, my husband was killed by it, and it was known as "Little Yeadwood School" in 1914 in the district.

Post Offices, Villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc., try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given; date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

"Yeadwood," was called that by the Indians on account of a growth of the grass on the banks of the Pothole Trace (a brownish color). The Indians called this to a traveler, and kept calling little bunches of tall grass "Little Yeadwood," on the South side, and the Yeadwood Hills was where we lived.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move to your district prior to 1930? Did many settle there permanently?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

By the name of William Brice was one of the officers of the district. He served under his successor, the late Mr. J. P. Smith, who was elected as the N.W.T. Representative at the first election in 1905. He also was President of the Board of Directors of the Little Rock School Board in 1942.

My husband was Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Little Rock School Board in 1912. We were elected at our first Annual Meeting in about 1920. Our later years as members of the Board were filled with hard work and dedication to the cause of education.

38. List all the places in your community by their names (school districts, townships, villages, etc.), and give the date of adoption (if any) and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

"Yoshawood" was called that by the Indians because of the growth of trees (a brownish color). The children often climbed these trees and played in the woods when they used "Little Yoshawood" on the Sixth Street side of the school.

One experience that stands out in my memory was when one fall day, my husband and I and a friend of ours rode up on horseback to visit my parents about five miles from our place.

After we had been there a short while a big wind got up, and we smelled smoke. So went out to see what was happening.

It was a big prairie fire, and was going towards our place. So we got on our horses and rode as fast as we could back home.

As we knew if it got a head of us our buildings and large hay stacks (the winter feed for our cattle and horses) would be burnt.

We were lucky enough to get back in time for my husband and friend to burn a back-fire. The only thing we lost was one hay stack which was a little way off from the rest. I will always remember this fire, as the rabbits were running a head of it.

We always had lots of horses on our ranch, as we were very fond of them.

I can remember so well when we had a large band of horses. They would run out for miles towards the East Mountain, as there were no fences in those days.

The horses would be rounded up once a year, and then turned out again. These horses were very wild, and would take a lot of breaking in. We had quite a large band in 1900, and many years after, and then the country started to get more settled.

My husband later imported thoroughbreds from Toronto, and also Shetland ponies. We raised and sold many of these horses.

And also we would race the thoroughbreds at the various race days held in the Touchwood Hills.
